Gentle ping to @nehanarkhede , do you think removing this file is still the right path forward or should we keep it and remove the comment?
(also cc @enothereska & @mjsax who seem to have done some related reviews).

**All test pass when I run them locally; however, one of them fails on Jenkins:**		
> JDK 8 and Scala 2.11 — Build finished. 4731 tests run, 0 skipped, **1 failed.**
> JDK 7 and Scala 2.10 — Build finished. 4801 tests run, 0 skipped, 0 failed.
> JDK 8 and Scala 2.12 — Build finished. 4801 tests run, 0 skipped, 0 failed.

https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.11/3151/consoleFull

```
kafka.controller.ControllerIntegrationTest > testPreferredReplicaLeaderElection FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: failed to get expected partition state upon broker startup
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$.fail(TestUtils.scala:311)
        at kafka.utils.TestUtils$.waitUntilTrue(TestUtils.scala:808)
        at kafka.controller.ControllerIntegrationTest.waitForPartitionState(ControllerIntegrationTest.scala:293)
        at kafka.controller.ControllerIntegrationTest.testPreferredReplicaLeaderElection(ControllerIntegrationTest.scala:210)
```
**My presumption is that particular test is not related with my commit changes at all; however, I tried to run that test locally multiple times and it passed successfully every time:**

Thanks for the review. Since this is a trivial test change and it will help us fix the build, I'll merge it after the PR builder is green.

I don't have a strong opinion. If this PR is updated to only contain the var -> val and `= Unit` change, then it's OK to merge it. We are not yet ready to remove these classes, but we should also not spend time on clean-ups as they are going away soonish.

Thanks for updating the patch. Merged to trunk.
retest this please

Hi, I think this is not the place where an infinite loop is needed. Otherwise, this leads to the fact that KafkaConsumer must be run in a separate thread, and need do a check on its state.

As I know, KafkaConsumer works on the principle of "long pull", that means

* no message on server - wait timeout and return empty array
* problem with request - wait timeout and return empty array
* problem with server (absent, etc.) - wait timeout and return empty array

KafkaConsumer dont have interface for check or ping cluster (or nodes). And it means that it is impossible to understand easily why we went into the loop.

I thought about adding TimeoutException (this can be seen at the first commit), but I preferred to make the most minimal changes to function workflow, because I'm honestly newbie.

This changes let me run normally my service in containers without kafka cluster and without startup stuck by loop in KafkaConsumer.
Chatted with @norwood offline, and we decided to go with the alternative direction to still log evicted records only after restoration.

Filed a new PR to see if it triggers the PR builder: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2915

I realized that the relationship between the LSO and the high watermark is trickier than I originally thought. I had assumed that it was sufficient to take the minimum of the two as the maximum offset that a client could fetch in READ_COMMITTED mode. The issue is when the COMMIT or ABORT marker itself is larger than the high watermark. We need to ensure that none of the records from the associated transaction becomes readable until the marker itself is replicated (even if the records have offsets lower than the high watermark). This requires a little more bookkeeping as we need to keep track of which transactions have been completed, but are not replicated. I'll update the patch as soon as I have a solution ready.

This PR passed the system tests after rebasing:
https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder-2/274/
@ijuma Could you kindly take some time to review this PR. Thanks.
@ewencp Could you kindly take some time to review this PR? Thanks.
Retest this please.

@hachikuji, I took care of all the major comments, and most of the minor ones. Main changes  include: 

1. Introduced more formal states to TransactionState and made the state transition checks more formal.
2. Stopped throwing exceptions from completion handlers.
3. If the Transaction is in ERROR state, the next transactional method will fail.
4. The transaction can be in error state if any transactional request or produce request within the transaction had a fatal error.

The only thing remaining is to cache errors from background requests like `AddPartitions` and `FindCoordinator` and propagate those on the next user-facing method. Currently we just log these errors. But that should be a minor change relatively speaking, so this is ready for review.

Call for review @enothereska @dguy @guozhangwang 

This is a follow-up for #2895 with the code cleanup commit that I did remove (moving around methods). I also put a second commit on top to improving logging. This PR also addresses as remaining nits from #2895
retest this please

@dguy @mjsax note that in some cases, instead of state store name, a StateStoreSupplier is provided. In my next commit I'll make that more consistent. @dguy I'm thinking the builder.table or builder.globaltable methods could also take a StateStoreSupplier, right? So if someone wants to materialize a source topic to an in-memory store that should be allowed.

Call for review @enothereska @dguy @guozhangwang 

This is part of KIP-120. I try try to break it down to multiple smaller PRs. This PR does not yet add any new public API (in case we get KIP-120 not finished for `0.11`), thus we can merge it as a preparation PR.

Note, that I change the API of `TopologyDescription` slightly -- instead of `List` I use `Set` -- I did update the KIP accordingly, too. Do we need to send a note to dev list about this update?

We were able to trigger this problem by running the test suite in a particular slave of Confluent Jenkins:

https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka-branch-builder/112/

Running the test suite with the fix:

https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka-branch-builder/115/
@ijuma @rajinisivaram can you have a look ?

@enothereska yes i think there should be some consistency. We also need to change `TopologyBuilder#addGlobalStore` to take a `StateStoreSupplier`.  The method also needs to disable logging. I'm wondering if we can piggy-back the change into this KIP? Otherwise we'll need to write another KIP just for that.

@dguy how important is it to change `TopologyBuilder#addGlobalStore` to take a `StateStoreSupplier`? With my latest commit it's the `globalTable` that takes a `StateStoreSupplier` and passes `StateStoreSupplier.get()`, i.e., a `StateStore` to `TopologyBuilder#addGlobalStore`.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/3176/
Test FAILed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

I will try to trigger another set of checks: 
https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Contributing+Code+Changes

> Despite our efforts, Kafka may have flaky tests at any given point, which may cause a build to fail. You can trigger a new build by adding the following comment: "retest this please". If the failure is unrelated to your pull request and you have been able to run the tests locally successfully, please mention it in the pull request.
@enothereska it is only for those using the PAPI directly. If they pass a StateStore that has loggingEnabled we have no way of telling. We need logging to be turned off.

Not that important since it's test code, but aside from just increasing correctness, it should also make tracking down some IT instabilities easier by not leaving dangling `Consumer` or `Producer` around on potential `send` or `poll` `Exception`s.
